In response to my question above you mentioned that you are dealing with the test utility dependencies by importing them from openwhisk.  However, looking at the code it looks like you are currently resolving the dependencies by pointing to the build output binaries in openwhisk (not good).  You should focus on the design of the openwhisk-catalog before removing any existing packages from openwhisk.

@mdeuser, instead of adding the original error message to the end of each new error message manually, why don't we just concatenate the old error message to the new one inside the MakeWskErrorFromWskError() method?

The separation into control and data planes seems largely orthogonal to the technological choices?

If the goal is sending large messages, doesn't it make more sense to configure Kafka in such a way that it can send large messages (possibly in chunks), or to use a messaging library that supports that?

It's not clear to me that a design where we emulate messages using a distributed cache as a store will be better. I don't see how it can positively affect latency, for instance.

I assume there are other, related, goals (such as having a consistent cache for the database, or keeping large payloads "off-heap" in the controller and/or the invokers while no containers are available). It would be good to list them explicitly.

The context for this is that docker 0.9 under load with concurrent operations (3+ threads) leads to docker daemon hangs and soft kernel panics.  Because of that, we maintain stability by serializing docker operations when issued from the invoker.  Docker 1.11.2 or 1.12 may change this as some of these bugs have been addressed.  Meanwhile, most operations must remain serial.  For this issue, the question is whether `docker pull` can be exempt from the lock without destabilizing the system.
IPG 304.
pls note https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/issues/622 which has also the same problem as yours. The root cause is https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/issues/199
IPG 306.

@dubeejw - Thanks for the review.  Here are a few reasons for keeping the message concatenation processing as it is.  Encapsulation - each error object is responsible and stores it's own error message; only pull in another object's error information when it is needed.  Secondly, while memory consumption is not really an issue for the CLI right now, concatenation the sub-error message would increase memory consumption for errors that are made up of a series of error objects.  Also, there's not much performance savings by concatenating each message during the error object construction since the CLI only calls toString() once.
IPG 307.

I need people's reviews an many as possible, since this is very crucial PR for us to install the catalog from openwhisk-catalog.

FWIW you don't need to `return` `whisk.done(...)` or `whisk.error(...)`.

There's an [example here](https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/blob/master/docs/actions.md#using-actions-to-call-an-external-api), for instance, where `whisk.done(..)` is called without `return`.
the first return is i think needed? it is there for flow control, not returning a value. i figured i'd leave the others, to avoid future regressions in control flow.

It is a user error to not terminate the control flow correctly as in this case - because the next time the action runs, if assigned to the same container, the call stack is not popped and so execution will resume for the previous call while also executing the new call.
`citool` is another set of subcommands we might consider adding to this.

@markusthoemmes FYI.

Revised proposal:
- All blocking action activations will return 20x regardless of `status/statusMessage` if the activation results in an activation record. the rationale is that the request completed and produced the activation record. The system did its job, it ran the action, and produced the activation record that includes the details of the activation.
- Blocking activations that are converted into non-blocking activations continue to return 202 (accepted). This can arise if the system is temporarily overloaded and the request was accepted but not yet processed completely.
- Blocking activations that fail with internal (system) errors will continue to yield a 50x response.

Of course for invoking an action that doesn't exit, or one that the subject is not authorized to, or if the subject does not authenticate, or if the request is throttled, or if the content payload is not a JSON object will return 40x level errors.

This simplifies the API and pushes the idea that the HTTP status code is not what you should rely on to determine if the activation result was what you expect it. This is also more in line with Lambda for reference: http://docs.aws.amazon.com/lambda/latest/dg/API_Invoke.html#API_Invoke_ResponseSyntax but where Lambda returns headers e.g., `X-Amz-Function-Error` whisk returns a JSON object with properties for status, log, the result, and other activation details.

For me, the magical 2 seconds is not needed anymore.  However, I was never able to reproduce this variant of the bug so my testing is not definitive.  I think our distributed tests also did not show this up so I think you will have to test this as it showed reliably in your setup.

`wsk package refresh` in an openwhisk deployment - from an end user perspective - will appear to be a bug in the CLI/backend because it's making a POST to the packages API. This route should be intercepted by nginx and an error (method not yet supported?) reported instead. @markusthoemmes thoughts on this?
IPG approved. Stashed into #894.

had a call with @sjfink on this -- summarizing here (steve, pls feel free to add / comment):
- we think anonymous rules make sense and we should support them
- we don't have a good real-world use case for named rules. however, will continue to support that for backwards compatibility and in case the need for them becomes higher-prio again.
- based on the previous bullet, the documented main stream flow for hooking up triggers and actions will not require to issue `wsk rule create` commands. Instead, we'll introduce a new command `wsk trigger associate <triggerName> <actionName>` and a corresponding `disassociate` command (can refine the verbs).
- we'll introduce the change above first on the cli and ui. Based on user adoption, we can gradually also change the api to support these verbs natively.

Do we need persistent disk at all or should we better start the container with a read-only filesystem? What are the use cases to have a persistent store within the container? One that would come in my mind is caching for multiple invocations within the same warm container... 

In case we need persistent disk I would further limit the tmpfs because memory is the limiting factor on invoker machines. maybe 64MB? (really depends on use cases we want to support).

For any larger storage we should probably think about mounting a docker volume. Where we would need to test carefully upfront to avoid performance and robustness issues.

@rabbah Yes, that's exactly the behaviour we had on our old CLI. We had that behaviour once, but checking the history of our nginx we seem to have lost it at some point? There used to be a route in there intercepting as you described.

In https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/issues/833#issuecomment-230635305 @sjfink suggested splitting this issue into others (implementation vs named/anonymous ...) so I am retitling this issue according to the focus implied by comment https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/issues/833#issuecomment-232882019.
maybe it was lost during ansible migration @lehoanganh @domdom82? will move this to an issue so as not to hijack this pull request.

So if I want to create a cloudant feed `T` to invoke an action `A` and use that rule in two different scenarios (read apps) `S1` and `S2`, and at some point I want to disable (pause) the rule for `S1` but not `S2`, I do that how if the rule is anonymous?

It is a mistake to make the rule anonymous always and state that we support it named only for legacy (backward compatibility) reasons. It means you are making all rules unique. To get back the functionality of having named ruled you will create more than one trigger for the scenario I describe which means two feeds instead - so you traded two rules for two feeds. A feed is more heavyweight (to manage) than a rule. Alternatively you trade two rules for two actions `A_S1` and `A_S2` which now means no shared code and updating the same action code twice when there is a need to change `A`, and still have to create the rule for `T` to `A_S1` and `A_S2`.

Now imagine more than 2 apps that want to consume the same feed but where you want to allow individual control over the rule. 

This isn't a hypothetical scenario either. Dark vision uses one cloudant feed and two rules, one for Watson vision analysis and the other for thumbnail generation. 

Further, what's the advantage of 
`wsk trigger associate triggerName actionName` vs 
`wsk rule create triggerName actionName` which we can add to create an anonymous rule and 
`wsk rule create ruleName triggerName actionName` where the rule is created with a name.

And what about `enable` and `disable` for the rule? You suggest these become trigger `associate` and `disassociate` which is more like rule `create` and `delete` so now enable/disable which afford the ability to pause/resume a rule without having to recreate it become create/delete.

So the totality of augmenting the CLI commands for triggers and the API for triggerrs is to bloat and conflate concerns for what is otherwise a simple API for orthogonal concepts.
PPG 849 approved.

one use case I can think of is a blackbox nodejs action that requires additional modules. those modules need to be installed somewhere.

other actions will also probably require some minimal /tmp space, but I think mainly custom user actions that need to pull in additional libs are the main target.

docker volumes are directly related to the storage driver. afaik only devicemapper gives you the option to attach lvm volumes of a definitive size. quotas also seem to be supported for devicemapper, zfs and btrfs. see https://github.com/docker/docker/issues/3804

but keep in mind that no disk-based storage will ever be as fast as memory. so it will take some time to make the volume and remove it after the action is done. this is where the charm of tmpfs comes into play.

if we assume a limit of 512 MB for /tmp and 512 MB memory limit for the container that makes 1 GB per container. but bear in mind that both memory and tmpfs are not allocated right away. if an action only takes like 64 MB then only that gets used.

I'd say on a 8 GB machine you could easily run 4-5 concurrent actions that use maximum resources without swapping.

Besides of the memory concern (a pretty huge one if you ask me, I don't think we can "waste" precious memory for container storage) we also need to make sure that "non-node-js" containers continue to work. Swift for example compiles the code on initialization of the container and thus needs to write that somewhere. Is that than also stored in `/tmp`, effectively reducing the quota the user has at hand?

Yes, of course. The memory vs. hd storage aside, we need to limit storage for containers. A user container is basically a function call. It should not have the need to store anything locally besides runtime data. Why would a stateless, serverless function need to store any data on a disk anyway?

The 512 MB limit is mostly helpful for blackbox containers where you are free to do whatever you like. When you are in a swift action or nodejs action, you are basically using a runtime instead of the naked container, so storing files on disk is even less relevant.

Besides, the user code can not rely on being in the same container the next time it gets invoked.

@rr - here's a proposal for the Go CLI implementation.  Sound reasonable?
1. `wsk genBashCompletion`  or similar command
2. In the current working directory, a file called `wsk_cli_bash_completion.sh` is generated
3. Run `. ./wsk_cli_bash_completion.sh`  also can add command to bash profile
4. Bash completion is enabled.

Go CLI is now available for download from openwhisk-dev, bluemix YS0, and bluemix YP.  Automated tests are also in place to validate the download from nginx.  I believe this issue can be closed.
